descriptionHtml: This project is the replacement of the legacy consumer prices micro edit and imputation system (Phoenix). This project aim to move away from the standard collection approach to today’s evolving collection strategies such as the retailer’s scanner data, web scrapping and web application programming interfaces (API).

milestones.title: " -User interfaces for manual capture and editing of price data "
" -Standardization for Unit of Measure and quality adjustments  "
" -The removal and application of taxes "
" -Automated imputations, edits and statistical treatments "
" -Representative Product and tax metadata modelling tools "
"  -Production cycle management features "
"  -Output data to the Prices Reporting Depot (PRAD)"
"  -Output data to Cygnus for index estimation "
"  -Ingesting data from a variety of pre-processing systems with different data layouts and variables "

items: (Completed) Sprint 69: 10% Design (Outlet), 55% Developement (SPO, PO, State matrix, Receive Data, RP Flags) 30% bugs (RP, TPO)

risks.title: IT staffing churn is causing delays in the project.
Increased frequency of basket updates could cause delays for CPD to do UAT activities
Due to shared IT project resources there is a risk that resource availability be reduced  which  may impact the schedule (SM, IT)
There is a risk that the design may impact other systems integration which may not be in-scope and accounted for in the budget.

Due to evolutions happening outside the division but as part of the corporate solutions there is a risk that we may be required to comply to and integrate to our solution  which could result in schedule change
Due to projects happening in parallel within the division, there is a risk that new requirements for the new system to come later in the process  which may introduce delays in the schedule

descriptionHtml: The Canadian Health Measure System Redesign project aims to implement a new platform to support the Canadian Health Measure Survey. The platform will include new tools for respondent collection, managing clinic sites and respondent appointments, tracking respondent specimen samples and integration with existing supporting health measures system.

milestones.title: MEC Application Redesign (CCPD is the lead)
RFP Procurement activities (CCPD is the lead)
AAW environment - Technical, User and Overhead Support (ADCPD is the lead)
IT integration of LIMS (CCPD is the lead)
Respondent Portal - MVP Solution (CCPD is the lead)
Accommodate Oral Health into existing MEC app (CCPD is the lead)

items:
MEC App Development:

  • Sprint 55 is currently underway and continues to focus on enhancements to the MEC to accomodate multiple health measure surveys.
  • Completed an LOA planning session with the support team from ITOS. Several deliverables were identified as well as the expected funding (~1.5 FTE)
  • The final LOA planning meeting is scheduled for March 18 and will focus on any remaining work items for the MEC App
    • The assumption is that integration between LIMS and MEC app will consume most of the work next FY so any remaining MEC app development will focus on critical functionality only.
  • Contacted CSD to inform them of the 4 security assessments that will be required for next FY and to get estimates for the work. The due dates to have these completed were also highlighted. The intent is to ensure they have capacity since our request this FY was deferred due to lack of capacity.

LIMS Procurement:

  • RFP posting is now closed. There were 6 bids.
  • The bid evaluation team has successfully completed the evaluation of the responses to the mandatory requirements for 5/6 bids. The remaining evaluation should be completed by March 15.
    • Only submissions that successfully meet the mandatory requirements will be considered for further evaluation (i.e. evaluating the rated requirements and financial bid)
    • There are a few responses to requirements that will require clarification from the bidder. PSPC will be engaged to coordinate the call back to those bidders.
  • Keeping this timeline for reference
    • Proposed timeline for the remaining activities:
      • Week of Dec 4/23: RFI posted
      • Week of Jan 8/24: RFP open to public
      • Week of Mar 4/24: Evaluate bids
      • Week of Mar 25/24: Winning bid identified, start contract negotiations

Respondent Portal

  • Completed Sprint 2 and delivered the second use case scenario: Register Respondent Account
  • Sprint 3 is currently in progress. This sprint will build upon the use case scenario delivered in sprint 2
  • Completed a second planning session for the LOA. The emphasis was placed on identifying the test results that will display to the respondent, what the format will look like and the required data points. CDHM has indicated they want results to be interactive and easy to understand but have provided little information or examples of what that means. Prototypes have been requested for no later than June 1.
  • A UX resource has been requested for next FY to help with design and/or prototypes elaboration.

name: (CHMS) Canadian Health Measure System Redesign

risks.title: Onboarding and Integration of LIMS
Procurement of LIMS
MEC IT Ecosystems - Architecture revamp
Content Delivery (EQ Specs) to Integrate in MEC App
Cloud cost for collection tools
Complexity of systems requirements could increase the scope of the project.
MEC Collection Mode - Outside of MEC (Home Visits, Temporary Space)
MEC IT Ecosystems - Infrastructure Revamp

descriptionHtml: Official repository for the procedure components of the Banff_redesign. Banff is a Statistics Canada generalized system that offers methods of editing and imputing survey data in the form of nine modules. The modules are easy to use and present a standard interface that is well documented. They offer methods that are known and have been approved at Statistics Canada.

items: Summary: The Banff and Banff processor python packages were released for internal client testing this month. We are currently working on an overall plan for the fiscal year and will be entering milestones shortly.
Completed: Internal client testing release: https://confluenceb.statcan.ca/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=1046112306
Completed: The deployment of the Banff web service to the dev Kubernetes cluster.

In progress: A plan to share the new Banff packages with internal and external clients, we will create a proposal for the steering committee and present it in June. This may include making the python packages available on the external GitHub and PyPI.
In progress: We are engaging Cyber Security and Centre of Expertise on Accessibility to plan for the corresponding assessments.

In progress: We are currently working on Sprint 18 which ends on May 6th. This includes converting the remaining two procedures from SAS to Python (VerifyEdits and EditStats). We are planning the development of Processor Controls for the Banff Processor, our business partners top priority feature for the remainder of the project. Logging improvements are also being made. For the Banff Service, the focus is autoscaling.

Upcoming: Performance testing of the Banff Processor and Process control Implementation. The Banff Procedure GitLab repo will be cleaned up and restructured. We will also look into standardizing “Out Status” files. For the Banff Service, we will look at a costing / charge-back plan and also dependency management.
Risk: Performance testing may result in the need for significant code refactoring. This was the case for the procedures, it may also be the case for the Banff Processor.
Risk: Client charge-back for the Banff Service may result in low usage or a tenancy for users to only use the underlying python packages. We will work on a chargeback plan next sprint.

Risk: Since Banff has been used in production for many years and there exists a large amount of metadata for the Banff Processor that is re-used every survey cycle, there is a conflict between making improvements and promoting better metadata and being backwards compatibility so that systems can migrate with ease. Providing backwards compatibility may promote old, bad habits and workarounds that are no longer required, while forcing new standards and approaches will trigger additional migration costs for clients.

name: Banff Redesign

risks.title: Potential schedule and cost variance resulting from dependency on staffing actions
Unexpected change in statistical processing environments
Changing Client Requirements
Risk of further delays to re-establish project team
Current resources (IT or Methodology) are re-allocated to other priorities
Changing resource costs

descriptionHtml: The goal of the Business Transformation project is to modernize employee workspaces through various business applications and visualizations tool, improving how we are managing our data assets, providing easier access to data across the agency with improved data governance and providing a processing platform where users will be able to run their jobs more efficiently and have the ability to scale up or down their environment to suit their needs that fall within their budget. Also included as part of this project is the SAS diversification initiative with the goal to be completely converted off SAS, to offer a more opened architecture and offer its new employees the tools they have learned on through their education.

items: 1st iteration of the solution - R and Python
The implementation team are experiencing some issues with implementing the R and Python environment
Working closely with the Cloud (NOC and NetApp CVO) teams to work through the issues
Daily scrum meetings have been set up to closely monitor progress and address issues as they appear
Cyber security is working closely with the team to help assess the controls that have been completed as part of the SA&A process to get an iATO/ATO for the environment
Training RFP
Datacamp licences will be distributed to a small subset of users starting March 4
Information on when STC employees will be able to access the Datacamp site will be distributed soon
Enterprise Architecture
The EA team completed a series of workshops to help identify the current state at STC by meeting with main leads for the mission critical systems that are part of the Business Continuity program
Gaps in STC architecture were identified and captured as part of the scope for the procurement exercise that Business Transformation will go through in FY2024-25
Agile procurement
Meetings have been taking place between STC and SSC since September 2023.

There were several discussions centered around who would be the project authority for the agile procurement that BT would like to start. Since BT is considering procuring a new data management solution, this is considered a business applicaton which falls under the authority of PSPC.

the latest meeting took place on Feb 28 between TBS, PSPC, SSC and STC. The goal was to discuss our proposed agile procurement request and also discuss if this could be considered an GoC initiative meaning that whatever we procure would become the GoC standard for data management.
It was decided that neither PSPC nor SSC have the capacity to run this agile procurement for STC.
STC will now look into running an RFI to start the exploration process and then if resources become available that can help us run an agile procurement, STC will consider switching at that time.

name: Business Transformation

risks.title: Limited resources capacity with administrator privileges for NetAPP at StatCan for manual onboarding to the Zone
Automated connectivity to Field filers via NetAppCVO configured based on specification from vendor is reporting an error
There is a risk that the new targeted enterprise architecture will not have the proper on-going funding support due to not having a plan in place within the agency to pay for it

There is a risk that we do not clearly understand the requirements of the agency due to lack of involvement of IT BA earlier in the project which may have an impact on the solution being widely accepted by the agency in general
There is a risk that the project will not be able to evaluate proposed solutions properly due to not having a proper testing environment available
There could be a gap in user expectations versus the delivered solution (the Zone)

Due to amount of inexperienced open-source users at STC, there is risk that their experience in the Zone will be limited which could result in resistance to change in not being able to see the immediate benefits of the Zone
Using the Zone in combination with still pulling data from filers and databases may have negative impacts on performance

descriptionHtml: Build a Flood Risk Awareness Portal to provide centralized flood risk information across Canada paired with actionable risk reduction guidance. Cost recovery project in partnership with the Department of Public Safety.

milestones.title: Deliver Solution Architecture and GC EARB Presentation
Evaluate riskprofiler.ca application
Deliver Internal Prototype

items: Status update as of 2024-03-18

Business Analysis

  • Info gathered from the UX Design interviews was shared with UX Design Team as input to the UX Design.
  • The user stories for the prototype (version to be delivered in December 2024) were completed with the PS Policy team and presented to the group at March 7th elaboration session
  • A document for non-functional requirements was created and elaborated in the GCXchange space.

UX Research

  • Completion of analysis and persona development
  • Sharing of findings and personas with UX Designer to help guide design
  • Development of final report and final presentation

UX Design

  • Creation of information architecture by combining insights from clients and user research
  • Work on wireframes started
  • Coming next are meetings with clients to clarify some questions that will impact design decisions.

Product Development

  • Completed deployment of proof of concept to dev and test https://flood-risk-portal.dev.cloud.statcan.ca/ https://flood-risk-portal.test.cloud.statcan.ca
  • Received location and credentials to NRCan's FIFRA Web

Mapping Service

  • Successfully consuming the FIFRA data from NRCan's datacube using latitude and longitude
  • Met with NRCan GEO.ca Team and have received separate location and credentials for a more customized service (latitude and longitude in, Flood Risk value out)
  • Had kickoff meeting with Dev team + UX designer and Developer to discuss project, timelines, deliverables etc.
  • Replacing Flood Susceptibility score with FIFRA score into proof of concept (ongoing)
Status update as of 2024-02-26

Project Management

  • Completed updates to GC EARB presentation slides following feedback from Preliminary GC EARB Review Meeting. Updated presentation sent to GC EARB in preparation for Feb 29th meeting.
  • Worked with service providers stakeholders to prepare costs estimates for two years implementation phase
  • Completed LoA between DSF and F8 for 2024-25 and 2025-26. LoA sent for Directors approvals.

Business Analysis

  • Continued working with PS Policy team to prioritize the list of user stories for the Prototype for Testing (December 2024 soft launch)
  • Planned an information gathering activity with select Public Safety requirement workshop participants (to take place on February 26 and 27)

User Research

  • Completed pre-analysis cleaning up and tagging of notes
  • Complete participant compensation administration
  • Started analysis of findings

Product Development, Planning and Management

  • Created first version of integrated implementatation plan
  • Included Flood Susceptibility index score in prototype
  • Onboarded prototype application in Cloud native environment (will deploy week of Feb 26)
  • Met with Seismic team members, discussed the issue, arranged for them will create a custom end point for us
  • Finalized cyber security intake submission
  • Worked on con-ops document (ongoing)

Project Management and oversight

  • LoA between DSF and F8 created and approved by Directors. Awaiting DGs signatures
  • High level estimates and high level scope of work for FY 2024-25 in progress. Close to completion
  • Engaged with NRCan to begin discussions on seismic data integration
  • Budget and deliverables tracking

Solution Architecture

  • Presentation to StatCan EARB completed
  • Follow-up action items from StatCan EARB completed and updated presentation sent to StatCan EARB for virtual approval
  • Updated target architecture to reflect FIFRA data being hosted with GEO.ca
  • Deck for GC EARB presentation finalized and ready to be sent to TBS

Business Analysis

  • User role model was defined for the portal

  • User story brainstorming has begun and should be completed this week

  • Confluence area set up for working area

  • All documents and minutes kept up-to-date on the GCXchange space

  • BAs, UX Research and UX Dev to begin adding UX Research results to BA work and designing wireframes based on the BA andUX Research work.

  • The next step is to prioritize the user stories. Once prioritized we will begin conversations about the highest priority user stories that will be implemented in version 1 of the portal (soft launch in December 2024). Those conversations will lead to acceptance criteria which become the functional requirements to be used by the Development team.

UX Research Update

  • Interviews
  • We’ve conducted 29 interviews to date (26 English, 3 French)
  • We have 8 interviews remaining between Jan.25-Jan.31st

Pre-Analysis/Analysis

  • We have begun cleaning up and organizing the notes from the interviews in preparation for full analysis
  • We have set up an ongoing meeting (starting Jan.31) between Rajat, Kerry, Manasi and us to share findings and discuss interdependencies

Public Awareness/Recruitment

  • The Consulting Canadians web mention cross link from PS consultations page to the Stats consultation page is live:
  • The social media recruitment campaign is ready to go for spring 2024 release (coincides with flood season)

Product Development

  • Completed:
    • Created free ArcGIS developer accounts
    • Obtained Cloud resources WID
    • Created small POC
    • Simple webpage, user can enter address
    • List of potential addresses presented to user
    • Chosen address returns precise latitude and longitude
  • Next step: Incorporate FIFRA dummy data when that service is available

Ongoing:

  • CSD intake form for Flood Risk Portal project
  • CONOPS for Flood Risk Portal project
  • Investigating Seismic APIs from NRCan

name: Flood Risk Portal

risks.title: Public Safety may decide to host and embed the portal within the GetPrepared.gc.ca, instead of a standalone portal

Due to administrative procedures with PS DSET Team getting into GEO.ca, there is a risk that the FIFRA data might not onboard into GEO.ca in time, which can result in the portal not being delivered on time
Due to uncertainty on the development of the FIFRA data, there is a risk that the FIFRA data may not be available on time, resulting in a delay in delivering the portal.

•	Due to the risk reduction content not being ready at this time, there is a risk that some content that need to be consumed are not in a consumable structure, which may result in a delay and additional costs for the portal.
Due to SSC taking over Cloud Operations from Statistics Canada soon, there is a risk that hosting and operations costs may increase, as well as a delay in delivering the portal.

Because the portal will point to external links, there is a risk that some links on the portal change or break without proper change management, which may result in broken links and a negative experience for the end user.

descriptionHtml: The Virtual Research Data Centre (vRDC) project, as an essential component of StatCan’s modernization agenda, will replace the current RDC infrastructure to advance the way academic researchers access and analyze StatCan data. By leveraging the current network to upgrade the infrastructure, the vRDC aims to increase the capacity of the RDC network to handle the advanced statistical analysis of large data files, facilitating more research activity and increasing productivity for all researchers. The vRDC will centralize computing resources, improve performance and disaster recovery, and support remote access for accredited RDC researchers across Canada. The infrastructure consists of two central servers located at the University of Waterloo (UW) and Simon Fraser University (SFU), as well as more than three hundred thin clients that will replace the local servers and workstations in the RDCs. The storage of StatCan's microdata files will be centralized at the UW and SFU servers, and all connections to the central servers will be protected via an encrypted Virtual Private Network (VPN).

milestones.title: " One time data repository downloads from STC Azure data lake storage to vRDC"
" Data Provisioning Point "
" Physical Inspection of vRDC infrastructure (Waterloo/Simon Fraser University)"
" vRDC Solution Penetration Testing "
" Design/Implement vRDC infrastructure services"
" Security Assessment and Accreditation Review & Verification"

items:
Executive Summary

  • Penetration tester is to be enrolled in May. Penetration test is planned for June.
  • Letter Of Agreement for 24-25 finalized, funding is being discussed.
  • StatCan SA&A evidence gathering is progressing ​

Accomplishments & Key Decisions

  • DSF management and CSD approved the StatCan cloud vm test environment for vRDC. It will be funded by DAS in 24-25 only. A meeting is set up to discuss monthly costs.
  • Cloud monitoring team to provide project team with standard setup of monitoring events, for the vRDC team to review list and provide final scope.
  • Backup services have been enabled by CRDCN. Reviewed backup strategy has been documented this week at this [location] https://jirab.statcan.ca/browse/VRDC_JIRA_A-22
  • CRDCN shared incident/change management contact info has been shared. ITOS to have acces and use the CRDCN SRM system.
  • Confirmed the approach and scope for the vRDC remote support to researchers via single session AVD. Initial estimation for 65 users per year is $16,356.60 ($251.64 per user). Additional savings are possible through
  • Professional services sole source contract is active and consultant has been provided with IT equipement.
  • The scope of the penetration test has been finalized and penetration tester enrollement planned in May. Penetration testing to start in June.
  • ITOS team documented the diagnosis and repair tools
  • Planning Technical Pilot which will start in about 3 weeks.
  • 24-25 vRDC LOA.
  • The Concept of Operations will continue to be updated until CRDCN have enough information to update their own portion​
  • CSD is developing a set of guardrails for CRDCN to abide by, to expedite the technology governance process. A draft documentation is still being reviewed.​
  • Ongoing Health check by ITOS Support on the infrastructure services​
  • StatCan SA&A evidence gathering is progressing ​

Next Steps

  • Submit a technology request for single AVDs for vRDC support staff, including ITOS.
  • DPP end-to-end testing activity.
  • Update RACI with the latest tabletop roles recommendations and backup roles.
  • DAD to create a support functional mailbox
  • StatCan staff to be registered and trained to use the CRDCN Service Management entry point
  • Conduct penetration testing​
  • Set up test environment for vRDC
  • Update the Incident Response Plan for vRDC and RACI, in collaboration with all stakeholders (IRP, RACI)
  • Capture the detailed IT plan & milestones and discussion minutes on [Confluence] https://confluenceb.statcan.ca/display/DAaaS/Virtual+Research+Data+Centre+%28VRDC%29+-+Integrated+Project+Blueprint+FY+23-24 (Ongoing)​

Risks

  • DSF needs to reach an acceptable level of expertise to be able to operate the solution ​
  • Absence of a Test Environment ​

Outstanding

  • Decide whether we need to upgrade SQL on the MIM Server (from v19 to v22) as recommended by DB hosting team, before production, or delay to later this summer.

name: vRDC - Virtual Research Data Centre

risks.title: Secure ongoing support connectivity solution has to be evaluated. How will StatCan employees connect to the vRDC? Will StatCan devices work?
A testing plan is needed for the identity solution
What is StatCan's involvement in the auditing/monitoring of the CRDCN-managed components of the vRDC infrastructure?
Security requirements not satisfied
Designing and implementing services of on premises infrastructure

Due to technical issues the Canadian Research Data Center Network (CRDCN), there is a risk that the delivery of CRDCN's infrastructure will be delayed, which will result in the vRDC not being delivered according to the schedule agreed.
Budget allocated is not sufficient
Changes required to the Identity Solution after the developer has left the project
Skills gap to operate the Identity solution

descriptionHtml: Enable the Toronto’s Ten-Year Community Safety and Well-Being Plan by building a SafeTO Collaborative Analytics and Learning Environment (SCALE) in DAS which will provide insights to the City of Toronto on social indicators & trends in different neighborhoods. The StatCan insights will allow the City of Toronto to better address its social development, Prevention, Risk intervention and Emergency Response goals, and ultimately build a city that promotes safety and well-being.

milestones.title: DAS Terms & Conditions
- Inbound data Review Process
-MVP2 - Build Monitoring reporting (OPMIC user auditing)
-MVP1 - Onboarding of the housing project

items:
Accomplishments, Updates & Key Decisions​

  • DAS-ITOS vm support SLA has been sent to DAD & ITOS ADs for review before signature. SLA document.​
  • Resolved PowerBI data exfiltration issues. Additional testing will be performed in a project workspace before production implementation
  • DAS IT finalized testing of Databricks and Synapse and they are now available to use on the DAS portal, by external users​.
  • eFT Data ingestion pipelines are still being tested by DAS IT.
  • Azure DevOps related WIF to unlock a production URL is still under review by CSD.
  • Privacy Impact Assessment is still being reviewed by OPMIC's team. ​DAS BO to follow up.
  • Additional external LOA clarifications are being addressed by SiS...DAS BO & team to meet with DAD to address Inbound SafeTo Data Review and data vetting Process.
  • T&Cs are being reviewed by OPMIC. Once T&Cs are final, DAS IT will update the popup page on DAS portal accordingly
  • Remaining 23-24 SafeTo activities plan is being tracked closely, for completion.​
  • Ongoing minutes of the weekly standup meeting and milestones progress on this integrated blueprint confluence page

Next Steps​

  • Remaining Gunviolence project deliverables (vms, external accounts, eFT accounts & user groups) pending LOA signature ​
  • Review the wording of the DAS T&Cs popup on the DAS portal once we receive the revised version
  • DAS Development team & sales engineer to enable & test Databricks and Synapse on the DAS portal, now that we obtained external identity solution iATO.
  • pm to finalize Internal LOA for DAS maintenance activities in 24-25.
  • Complete Azure DevOps documentation before onboarding of users​

Outstanding​

  • External LOA is still under review by City of Toronto, for signature​
  • PIA still under review by OPMIC​

Risks

  • Risk of carrying a deficit into 24-25 if we delay completion of 23-24 LOA activities.​

descriptionHtml: Statistics Canada has identified a number of Service Management processes that are critical or important to business service delivery, yet inefficient to respond to current and upcoming business requirements for a responsive, agile, flexible and Modern IT service delivery. The purpose of this project is to address these issues by designing and implementing a solution that supports the full ITSM processes.

items: The project is moving to Production

name: (ESMS) Service Management Solution

Complexity, potential changes to requirements and data quality of integration points may impact project schedule and cost
